en.sc1: Assume that there are n elements in the queue. By analogy to the ArrayList implementation, we could require that all elements of the queue be stored in the first $n$ positions of the array.
en.sc2: If we choose the last element of the queue to be the "last" element in the ArrayList at position size-1, then an enqueue operation is equivalent to an append operation on a list. This requires only $O(1)$ time.
en.sc3: However, a dequeue operation requires $O(n)$ time, because in order to remove the first element, all of the elements must be shifted down by one position to retain the property that the remaining $n-1$ queue elements reside in the first $n-1$ positions of the array.
en.sc4: If we tried flipping things around and chose the last element of the queue to be in position 0, then dequeue operations require only $O(1)$ time because the first element of the queue (the one being removed) is the element in position size-1 of the ArrayList.
en.sc5: However, now enqueue operations will require $O(n)$ time, because the n elements currently in the queue must each be shifted one position in the ArrayList.
